Concrete Compressive Strength 

---------------------------------

Abstract: Concrete is the most important material in civil engineering. The 
concrete compressive strength is a highly nonlinear function of age and 
ingredients. These ingredients include cement, blast furnace slag, fly ash, 
water, superplasticizer, coarse aggregate, and fine aggregate.

---------------------------------

Sources: 

  Original Owner and Donor
  Prof. I-Cheng Yeh
  Department of Information Management 
  Chung-Hua University, 
  Hsin Chu, Taiwan 30067, R.O.C.
  e-mail:icyeh@chu.edu.tw
  TEL:886-3-5186511

  Date Donated: August 3, 2007
 
---------------------------------

Data Characteristics:
    
The actual concrete compressive strength (MPa) for a given mixture under a 
specific age (days) was determined from laboratory. Data is in raw form (not scaled). 

Number of instances (observations): 1030

title: DWD dataset #4
text:
dc_reflib’s notes
The link to the original dataset appears to be dead, although the dwd.de site is still around. The units are reasonable guesses but cannot be confirmed without access to the original data.






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
There may be a relationship between altitude and average sunshine in Argentina (discussed in this paper) but those authors argue that the relationship stems from Argentina’s lower elevations being more heavily wooded. This statement may or may not be true for Germany (i.e., the area covered by this data set), but the general relationship of elevation causing more or less average sunshine does not appear to be true. This ground truth cannot be verified by reference, as far as I can tell.

title: DWD dataset #2
text:
dc_reflib’s notes
The link to the original dataset appears to be dead, although the dwd.de site is still around. The units are reasonable guesses but cannot be confirmed without access to the original data.






Operational Causality



“Physics” 
There is a relationship between altitude and precipitation (see, e.g., here) but it is often considered a by-product of the altitude and atmospheric temperature relationship (see this dataset). This data uses multi-decade time averages (or maybe totals?) for the precipitation and includes no information regarding the altitude samples over that time period.

dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Engineered” 
This dataset was originally part of the Hipel-McLeod Time Series Datasets Collection. The description provided in that dataset collection for this specific dataset is “original data from a paper by D. Pack”, which is less than helpful. A couple of emails reveals the data to come from a proposed environmental control system akin to a thermostat in a residential home. It was never made clear if this data is empirical or simulated.

Information for pairs0039:

Pima Indians Diabetes Database

1. Sources:
   (a) Original owners: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and
                        Kidney Diseases
   (b) Donor of database: Vincent Sigillito (vgs@aplcen.apl.jhu.edu)
                          Research Center, RMI Group Leader
                          Applied Physics Laboratory
                          The Johns Hopkins University
                          Johns Hopkins Road
                          Laurel, MD 20707
                          (301) 953-6231
   (c) Date received: 9 May 1990

2. Past Usage:
    1. Smith,~J.~W., Everhart,~J.~E., Dickson,~W.~C., Knowler,~W.~C., \&
       Johannes,~R.~S. (1988). Using the ADAP learning algorithm to forecast
       the onset of diabetes mellitus.  In {\it Proceedings of the Symposium
       on Computer Applications and Medical Care} (pp. 261--265).  IEEE
       Computer Society Press.

       The diagnostic, binary-valued variable investigated is whether the
       patient shows signs of diabetes according to World Health Organization
       criteria (i.e., if the 2 hour post-load plasma glucose was at least 
       200 mg/dl at any survey  examination or if found during routine medical
       care).   The population lives near Phoenix, Arizona, USA.

3. Relevant Information:
      Several constraints were placed on the selection of these instances from
      a larger database.  In particular, all patients here are females at
      least 21 years old of Pima Indian heritage.  

4. Number of Instances: 768

x: age

y: 2-Hour serum insulin (mu U/ml)


ground truth:
x --> y


UPDATE v1.0: We only kept the instances with nonzero value for serum insulin,
because we believe these encode for missing values. From the UCI ML webpage:
"UPDATE: Until 02/28/2011 the UCI ML web page indicated that there were no
missing values in the dataset. As pointed out by a repository user, this cannot
be true: there are zeros in places where they are biologically impossible, such
as the blood pressure attribute. It seems very likely that zero values encode
missing data. However, since the dataset donors made no such statement we
encourage you to use your best judgement and state your assumptions."

The link to the original dataset appears to be dead, although the dwd.de site is still around. The units are reasonable guesses but cannot be confirmed without access to the original data.






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
There is a relationship between latitude and precipitation (see, e.g., here) but not longitude, at least on a global scale. This data covers only Germany, but there does not seem to be a clear relationship between longitude and precipitation even across that restricted space. This ground truth cannot be verified by reference, as far as I can tell.

missing values in the dataset. As pointed out by a repository user, this cannot
be true: there are zeros in places where they are biologically impossible, such
as the blood pressure attribute. It seems very likely that zero values encode
missing data. However, since the dataset donors made no such statement we
encourage you to use your best judgement and state your assumptions."

It seems this data was collected specifically to test cause-effect machine learning algorithms. Notice that 16,823 samples with one sample collected every five minutes is almost 57 days of collecting. I cannot find any discussion of data collection methods or error.

text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0066:

Financial data

x:  stock returns of Hutchison (0013.HK)

y:  stock return of Cheung kong (0001.HK)

from Jan. 4, 2000 to Jun. 17, 2005. Data was obtained from the Yahoo finance database. Cheung kong owns about 50% of Hutchison.

Remark: We calculated the above returns from the raw data in the following way.
1. Extract the dividend/split adjusted closing price data from Yahoo Finance http://finance.yahoo.com/.
2. For the few days when the price is not available, we use simple linear interpolation to estimate the price.  Consequently the two time series are aligned.
3. For each stock, denote the closing price on day t by P_t, and the corresponding return is calculated by X_t = (P_t-P_{t-1 }) / P_{t-1 }.

ground truth:
x-->y

title: Stock returns (Hutchison and Cheung Kong)
text:
dc_reflib’s notes
Historical stock prices are still available on Yahoo Finance.






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
Causal relationships in stock markets are notoriously difficult to pin down. This research goes back to Granger and the beginnings of modern data causality research. Personally, I would take this implied causal relationship with a grain of salt. Here are some articles discussing stock market causality if you want to dive deeper: Networks of causal relationships in the U.S. stock market and Time-varying pattern causality inference in global stock markets.

title: Ball on mystery track #3
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0102:

position vs. passing time

pair0102, pair0103, pair0104 are taken from the same run of an experiment at a ball track for children at which some sensors have been mounted to measure the following parameters:

variable 1: position on the ball track where the ball starts
variable 2: time interval between passing the first and the second light barrier.
variable 3: time interval between passing the third and the fourth light barrier.

The initial part of the track ("acceleration zone")
has large slope, therefore the initial position is decisive for the speed the ball  gets when it rolls downwards. Therefore and because of the order of the light barriers we have the following causal chain:

variable 1 ---> variable 2 --> variable 3 

here we have x= variable 1, y= variable 2

The data has been measured by D. Janzing in August 2016. 


ground truth x->y

title: Snowfall and temperature
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Physics” 
Snow accumulation requires colder temperatures. A discussion of snow formation in general can be found here. (Colder temperatures do not cause more snow, but if snow is falling, then it cannot accumulate without freezing temperatures. Despite the notes in the original data description, the relationship between snow accumulation and temperature is subtly causal.)

title: Milking frequency and protein concentration
text:
Original documentation
Description of pair0085:

This data set is extracted from that for the milk protein trial used by Verbyla and Cullis (1990).  The original data set consists of assayed protein content of milk samples taken weekly from each of 79 cows.  The cows were randomly allocated to one of three diets: barley, mixed barley-lupins, and lupins, with 25, 27, and 27 cows in the three groups, respectively.  Measurements were taken for up to 19 weeks, but there were 38 drop-outs from week 15 onwards, corresponding to cows who stopped producing milk before the end of the experiment.

We removed the missing values (drop-outs) in the data set: we did not consider the measurements from week 15 onwards, which contain many drop-outs, and we discarded the cows with drop-outs before week 15.  Finally, the data set contains 71 cows and 14 weeks.  Furthermore, we re-organized the data set to see the relationship between the milk protein and the time to take the measurement:

X : time to take weekly measurements (from 1 to 14).

Y : protein content of the milk produced by each cow at time X.


Group truth: 

X -> Y.


Remark:

Here we do not consider the effect of the diets on the protein content.  Note that rigorously speaking, X, together with the diets, causes Y.

The original data set is available at
http://www.maths.lancs.ac.uk/Software/Oswald/


Reference:
A. P. Verbyla and B. R. CullisSource, "Modelling in Repeated Measures Experiments", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society. Series C (Applied Statistics), Vol. 39, No. 3(1990), pp. 341-356.

“Physics” 
There is some evidence that more frequent milking of diary cows might cause higher protein concentrations in their milk. See, e.g., this article and this meta-study. The original data source is no longer available.

Information for pair0102:

position vs. passing time

pair0102, pair0103, pair0104 are taken from the same run of an experiment at a ball track for children at which some sensors have been mounted to measure the following parameters:

variable 1: position on the ball track where the ball starts
variable 2: time interval between passing the first and the second light barrier.
variable 3: time interval between passing the third and the fourth light barrier.

The initial part of the track ("acceleration zone")
has large slope, therefore the initial position is decisive for the speed the ball  gets when it rolls downwards. Therefore and because of the order of the light barriers we have the following causal chain:

variable 1 ---> variable 2 --> variable 3 

here we have x= variable 1, y= variable 3

The data has been measured by D. Janzing in August 2016. 


ground truth x->y

Light Response Data

Taken at a flux tower at site DE-Hai
latitude: 51.08?N
longitude: 10.45?E

The filtered version of the data is taken from:

Moffat A.M. (2012): Assessing competing semi-empirical equations:
Light response curve (Chapter 7). In: /A new methodology to interpret
high resolution measurements of net carbon fluxes between terrestrial
ecosystems and the atmosphere/. pp. 68-80. Doctoral thesis, Friedrich
Schiller University, Jena.

- Response of NEP on total PPFD

First column (x): PPFD (Photosynthetic Photon Flux Density)
- a measure of light intensity in terms of photons, that are available for photosynthesis
- i.e. the number of photons falling on a 1 meter square area per second
- only the photons with a wavelength of 400-700nm (visible light) are available for photosynthesis
- unit [?mol/(m?s)]
PPFD(total) = PPFDdif + PPFDdir


Second column (y): NEP (Net Ecosystem Productivity)
- a measure of the carbon flux
- calculated by photosynthetic uptake MINUS release by respiration
- is known to be driven by PPFD
- unit: [?mol/(m?s)]

title: Fine root decomposition data (grasslands)
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Physics” 
The original paper is available here: Factors controlling decomposition rates of fine root litter in temperate forests and grasslands. Appeals to “common sense” are always dangerous in causality studies, and this example is no different. There seems to be a causal relationship between mass loss at 6 months and 12 months but it depends on factors such as soil temperature and moisture. Be sure to read the paper to understand the subtleties here.

Original documentation
Information for pair0107:

Direction of Gabor patches

The data set is from a psychophysics experiments with human subjects. A screen shows tilted Gabor patches (which are patterns of stripes
frequently used as stimuli in psychological experiments), either tilted to the left or to the right. The subject are asked to infer the direction, while the patches are shown with stronger or weaker contrast. The variable X describes the contrast values ranging from 0.0150 to 0.0500 in steps of 0.0025. The variable Y is a binary indicating whether the direction has been identified correctly (Y=1) or not (Y=0). For low values of the contrast the fraction of correct decisions approaches chance level (50%).


First column (x): contrast

Second column (y): answer correct or not

The data set has been recorded by Heiko Schütt in 2014. 


ground truth x -> y

title: Gabor patch orientation and contrast
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
There is a lot of literature regarding Gabor patches (see, e.g., Effect of contrast on the perception of moving multiple Gabor patterns) but I cannot find any support for a causal link between contrast and orientation perception.

title: (Young adult) spinal bone density and age
text:
Original documentation
x = age
y = Relative Spinal bone mineral density

Source:

"bone" data set from http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ElemStatLearn/ElemStatLearn.pdf

We obtained and preprocessed the data using the following R commands:

install.packages('ElemStatLearn')
library(ElemStatLearn)
boneuniq = bone[1,]
for( i in 2:dim(bone)[1] ) { 
  if( bone[i,1] != bone[i-1,1] ) { 
    boneuniq <- rbind(boneuniq,bone[i,])
  } 
}
write.table(boneuniq[,c(2,4)],file='/tmp/bone.csv',row.names=FALSE,col.names=FALSE)
remove.packages('ElemStatLearn')

For the preprocessing, we only take the first measurement for each child, and 
selected only the columns "age" and "spnbmd" (Relative Change in Spinal BMD).

The ground truth should be that age causes relative change in spinal BMD.

title: (Young adult) spinal bone density and age
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
The original dataset has been removed from CRAN (but archives of past version are still available). Spinal bone density increases in children based on a collection of causal factors and then remains roughly constant until later stages of life. See, e.g., this study. It is unclear why this dataset purports spinal bone density should change (causally or otherwise) for young adults as they age.

title: Photosynthetic ecosystem productivity #3
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0080:

Light Response Data

Taken at a flux tower at site DE-Hai
latitude: 51.08?N
longitude: 10.45?E

The filtered version of the data is taken from:

Moffat A.M. (2012) Assessing competing semi-empirical equations:
Light response curve (Chapter 7). In: /A new methodology to interpret
high resolution measurements of net carbon fluxes between terrestrial
ecosystems and the atmosphere/. pp. 68-80. Doctoral thesis, Friedrich
Schiller University, Jena.

- Response of NEP on PPFDdir

First column (x): NEP (Net Ecosystem Productivity)
- a measure of the carbon flux
- calculated by photosynthetic uptake MINUS release by respiration
- is known to be driven by PPFDdif and PPFDdir
- unit: [?mol/(m?s)]

Second column (y): PPFDdir (Photosynthetic Photon Flux Density, direct)
- a measure of direct solar light intensity in terms of photons, that are available for photosynthesis
- i.e. the number of direct photons falling on a 1 meter square area per second
- only the photons with a wavelength of 400-700nm (visible light) are available for photosynthesis
- unit [?mol/(m?s)]
PPFD(total) = PPFDdif + PPFDdir


ground truth

y -> x

title: Socio-economic status and language tests
text:
Original documentation
Dataset 'nlschools' from the R MASS package. 

According to the description in the documentation of the package 
(https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MASS/MASS.pdf ):

"Snijders and Bosker (1999) use as a running example a study of 2287 eighth-grade pupils (aged
about 11) in 132 classes in 131 schools in the Netherlands.

Source:
Snijders, T.A.B. and Bosker, R.J. (1999)
'Multilevel Analysis. An Introduction to Basic and Advanced Multilevel Modelling.'
London: Sage."

We converted the data to a text file by the following R commands:

library('MASS')
write.matrix(nlschools,file='/tmp/nlschools.txt')

X = the first column ('lang', language test score) 
Y = the fifth column ('SES', social-economic status of pupil's family) column. 

We consider SES to be one of the causes of lang, but note that selection bias may be
present (via the choice of the classes and schools).

Ground truth:  Y -> X

The original data source is still available here, here, or here. The original source focused on statistical, not causal, analysis. There is, however, some relevant discussion on whether or not SES is a causal driver of test scores.

Concrete Compressive Strength 

---------------------------------

Abstract: Concrete is the most important material in civil engineering. The 
concrete compressive strength is a highly nonlinear function of age and 
ingredients. These ingredients include cement, blast furnace slag, fly ash, 
water, superplasticizer, coarse aggregate, and fine aggregate.

---------------------------------

  Prof. I-Cheng Yeh
  Department of Information Management

  e-mail:icyeh@chu.edu.tw
  TEL:886-3-5186511

  Date Donated: August 3, 2007
 
---------------------------------

Data Characteristics:
    
The actual concrete compressive strength (MPa) for a given mixture under a 
specific age (days) was determined from laboratory. Data is in raw form (not scaled). 

Number of instances (observations): 1030

Information for pair0067:

Financial data

x:  stock returns of Cheung kong (0001.HK)

y:  stock return of Sun Hung Kai Prop. (0016.HK)

from Jan. 4, 2000 to Jun. 17, 2005. Data was obtained from the Yahoo finance database. Sun Hung Kai Prop. is a typical stock in the Hang Seng Property subindex, and is believed to depend on other majoy stocks.

Remark: We calculated the above returns from the raw data in the following way.
1. Extract the dividend/split adjusted closing price data from Yahoo Finance http://finance.yahoo.com/.
2. For the few days when the price is not available, we use simple linear interpolation to estimate the price.  Consequently the two time series are aligned.
3. For each stock, denote the closing price on day t by P_t, and the corresponding return is calculated by X_t = (P_t-P_{t-1 }) / P_{t-1 }.

Historical stock prices are still available on Yahoo Finance.






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
Causal relationships in stock markets are notoriously difficult to pin down. This research goes back to Granger and the beginnings of modern data causality research. Personally, I would take this implied causal relationship with a grain of salt. Here are some articles discussing stock market causality if you want to dive deeper: Networks of causal relationships in the U.S. stock market and Time-varying pattern causality inference in global stock markets.

title: Ball on mystery track #2
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0098

initial and final speed of a ball on a ball track for children

The data has been recorded by Dominik Janzing using a ball track that has been equipped with two pairs of light barriers. The first pair measures the initial speed
 and the second pair the speed of a ball at some later position of the track. The units of the speeds are arbitrary and differ for both measurements (X and Y) since they are obtained by
inverting the time the ball needed to pass the distance between two light barriers of one pair. 
 
 The initial part of the track ("acceleration zone")
has large slope. The initial speed is strongly determined by the exact position where the ball is put on the acceleration zone. For part of the runs, the position of the ball has been chosen by D. Janzing, the other part by a 4-year old child. This should avoid that the variation of the initial position is done in a too systematic way. 
The setup is actually the same as for pair0097, but for pair0098 the ball track had a longer acceleration zone, which allows for larger deviations of the initial speed. 

Ground truth

x - - > y

title: Ball on mystery track #5
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0102:

position vs. passing time

pair0102, pair0103, pair0104 are taken from the same run of an experiment at a ball track for children at which some sensors have been mounted to measure the following parameters:

variable 1: position on the ball track where the ball starts
variable 2: time interval between passing the first and the second light barrier.
variable 3: time interval between passing the third and the fourth light barrier.

The initial part of the track ("acceleration zone")
has large slope, therefore the initial position is decisive for the speed the ball  gets when it rolls downwards. Therefore and because of the order of the light barriers we have the following causal chain:

variable 1 ---> variable 2 --> variable 3 

here we have x= variable 2, y= variable 3

There is an important difference to pair0097 and pair0098 where the variables where given by the
inverse of the time (i.e. the speed) to pass a pair of light barriers. Here we report the time itself.


The data has been measured by D. Janzing in August 2016. 


ground truth x->y

title: Ball on mystery track #5

Concrete Compressive Strength 

---------------------------------

Abstract: Concrete is the most important material in civil engineering. The 
concrete compressive strength is a highly nonlinear function of age and 
ingredients. These ingredients include cement, blast furnace slag, fly ash, 
water, superplasticizer, coarse aggregate, and fine aggregate.

---------------------------------

Sources: 

  Original Owner and Donor
  Prof. I-Cheng Yeh
  Department of Information Management 
  Chung-Hua University, 
  Hsin Chu, Taiwan 30067, R.O.C.
  e-mail:icyeh@chu.edu.tw
  TEL:886-3-5186511

  Date Donated: August 3, 2007
 
---------------------------------

Data Characteristics:
    
The actual concrete compressive strength (MPa) for a given mixture under a 
specific age (days) was determined from laboratory. Data is in raw form (not scaled). 

Number of instances (observations): 1030
---------------------------------

Name  -- Description

Water -- kg in a m3 mixture 
Concrete compressive strength -- MPa

title: Fine root decomposition data (forests)
text:
Original documentation
x = Mass loss OCTOBER 2012 in %
y = Mass loss APRIL 2012 in %

Fine root decomposition data. 150 Litterbags containing fine roots were put underground to
study decomposition rates in different ecosystems. This data set contains all experiments done in forests.
y denotes the mass loss 6 months after the start of the experiment.
y denotes the mass loss 1 year after the start of the experiment.
Plots with missing data were excluded.

Data taken from
Solly et al (2014). Factors controlling decomposition rates of fine root litter in temperate forests and grasslands. Plant and Soil, 382(1-2), 203-218.

Common sense tells us that at a certain point in time the total material decomposed depends on the amount decomposed at an earlier point in time.

y --> x

title: Fine root decomposition data (forests)
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Physics” 
The original paper is available here: Factors controlling decomposition rates of fine root litter in temperate forests and grasslands. Appeals to “common sense” are always dangerous in causality studies, and this example is no different. There seems to be a causal relationship between mass loss at 6 months and 12 months but it depends on factors such as soil temperature and moisture. Be sure to read the paper to understand the subtleties here.

missing values in the dataset. As pointed out by a repository user, this cannot
be true: there are zeros in places where they are biologically impossible, such
as the blood pressure attribute. It seems very likely that zero values encode
missing data. However, since the dataset donors made no such statement we
encourage you to use your best judgement and state your assumptions."

title: Auto-Mpg Data #1
text:
dc_reflib’s notes
Units are not discussed in the original data description. The link to the original dataset is working:
UCI ML Repo






Operational Causality



“Physics” 
If the number of gallons a car holds is fixed, then this relationship is a tautology. If, e.g., a car has a 16 gallon tank, then a total displacement of 32 miles “causes” a miles per gallon of 2. Of course, this works both ways; i.e., a fixed rate of 2 miles per gallon “causes” a displacement of 32 miles for a 16 gallon tank.

title: Stirling engine
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair 108:

This pair shows the dependence of the inverse velocity and the temperature of the heat bath of a Striling engine. The engine is
driven by a cup of hot water that is put underneath.
The inverse velocity is measured by the time needed for the engine's wheel for 1/6 rotation (because the wheel has 6 radius arms). 
The temperature is measured by a sensor that was put into the cup. 



First column (x): time for 1/6 rotation

Second column (y): temperature in Degree Celsius

The data set has been recorded by Dominik Janzing in 2017


ground truth x <- y

title: Stirling engine
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Engineered” 
The experimental design description is incomplete (like the ball-on-track data sets). Stirling engines are well-studied heat engines. The “reasonable” assumption here is that an increase in temperature corresponds to an increase in pressure. Stirling engine analyses typically discuss pressure and volume to avoid this sometimes-troublesome assumption. A good discussion of these concepts can be found in the Stirling cycle Wikipedia article. This dataset presumes temperature causes output work from the engine in the same way energy is typically considered a causal driver in this system (see Fig. 6 of the Stirling cycle article).

title: CPU performance
text:
Original documentation
Dataset 'cpus' from the R MASS package. 

According to the description in the documentation of the package 
(https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MASS/MASS.pdf ):

"A relative performance measure and characteristics of 209 CPUs.

Source:
P. Ein-Dor and J. Feldmesser (1987) 
'Attributes of the performance of central processing units: a relative performance prediction model.'
Comm. ACM. 30, 308–317"

We converted the data to a text file by the following R commands:

library('MASS')
write.matrix(cpus,file='/tmp/cpus.txt',sep=',')

X = logarithm of the second column ('syct', cycle time in nanoseconds)
Y = logarithm of the seventh column ('perf', published performance on a benchmark mix relative to an IBM 370/158-3)

We consider syct to be one of the causes of perf.

Ground truth:  X -> Y

Operational Causality

The original data source is still available here, here, or here. The original source focused on statistical, not causal, analysis. CPU cycle times, however, are often considered the primary driver of performance (see, e.g., this article).

title: Stock returns (Hang Seng Bank and HSBC)
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0065:

Financial data:

x:  stock returns of Hang Seng Bank (0011.HK) 

y:  stock return of HSBC Hldgs (0005.HK) 

from Jan. 4, 2000 to Jun. 17, 2005. Data was obtained from the Yahoo finance database. HSBC owns about 60% of Hang Seng Bank.

Remark: We calculated the above returns from the raw data in the following way.
1. Extract the dividend/split adjusted closing price data from Yahoo Finance http://finance.yahoo.com/.
2. For the few days when the price is not available, we use simple linear interpolation to estimate the price.  Consequently the two time series are aligned.
3. For each stock, denote the closing price on day t by P_t, and the corresponding return is calculated by X_t = (P_t-P_{t-1 }) / P_{t-1 }.

ground truth:
x-->y

title: Stock returns (Hang Seng Bank and HSBC)
text:
dc_reflib’s notes
Historical stock prices are still available on Yahoo Finance.






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
Causal relationships in stock markets are notoriously difficult to pin down. This research goes back to Granger and the beginnings of modern data causality research. Personally, I would take this implied causal relationship with a grain of salt. Here are some articles discussing stock market causality if you want to dive deeper: Networks of causal relationships in the U.S. stock market and Time-varying pattern causality inference in global stock markets.

“I don’t know.” 
There is a relationship between latitude and temperature (see, e.g., here) but not longitude, at least on a global scale. This data covers only Germany, but there does not seem to be a clear relationship between longitude and temperature even across that restricted space (see, e.g., this map). This ground truth cannot be verified by reference, as far as I can tell.

title: RGB pixel intensity
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0101:

Brightness of screen

This is from an experiment that has been performed to generate an example of a cause-effect relation
that is clearly unconfounded.

First column (x): grey value of a pixel that is chosen randomly from a fixed image. The grey value
is displayed by the color of a square on a computer screen

Second column (y): light intensity seen by a photo diode placed several centimeters away from the screen.  

More precisely, the light intensity is measured by the 
Adafruit TSL2591 High Dynamic Range Digital Light Sensor connected to an Arduino microcontroler. 
https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-tsl2591/wiring-and-test

The measurement has been performed by D. Janzing in August 2016.

ground truth x->y

title: RGB pixel intensity
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“Engineered” 
The experimental design description is incomplete (like the ball-on-track data sets). However, “reasonable” assumptions in this case imply that this is an engineered system where changing the RGB values of a pixel changes it’s intensity by definition (although see this discussion of some nuances), which might be considered causal when only the RGB values are manipulated (i.e., same monitor, same geometry, etc.).

title: Ball on mystery track #1
text:
Original documentation
Information for pair0097

initial and final speed of a ball on a ball track for children

The data has been recorded by Dominik Janzing using a ball track that has been equipped with two pairs of light barriers. The first pair measures the initial speed
 and the second pair the speed of a ball at some later position of the track. The units of the speeds are arbitrary and differ for both measurements (X and Y) since they are obtained by
inverting the time the ball needed to pass the distance between two light barriers of one pair. 
 
 The initial part of the track 
has large slope. The initial speed is strongly determined by the exact position where the ball is put on the track. For part of the runs, the position of the ball has been chosen by D. Janzing, the other part by a 4-year old child. This should avoid that the variation of the initial position is done in a too systematic way. 

Ground truth

x - - > y

title: Ball on mystery track #1
text:
dc_reflib’s notes






Operational Causality



“I don’t know.” 
Unfortunately there’s not enough information in the original data description to understand why we might expect the initial position of the ball to have any influence on the final position. If we make reasonable assumptions, like the track is located on Earth and so on, then we’re still left with the question of the track shape. I believe we are meant to assume the track is a ramp (“large slope”) and the initial position is at the top of the ramp with a final position somewhere after the ball has stopped accelerating due to gravity. That might be a fair assumption, but there’s not enough information here to have any confidence in it.

Information for pair0079:

Light Response Data

Taken at a flux tower at site DE-Hai
latitude: 51.08?N
longitude: 10.45?E

The filtered version of the data is taken from:

Moffat A.M. (2012) Assessing competing semi-empirical equations:
Light response curve (Chapter 7). In: /A new methodology to interpret
high resolution measurements of net carbon fluxes between terrestrial
ecosystems and the atmosphere/. pp. 68-80. Doctoral thesis, Friedrich
Schiller University, Jena.

- Response of NEP on PPFDdif

First column (x): NEP (Net Ecosystem Productivity)
- a measure of the carbon flux
- calculated by photosynthetic uptake MINUS release by respiration
- is known to be driven by PPFDdif and PPFDdir
- unit: [?mol/(m?s)]

Second column (y): PPFDdif (Photosynthetic Photon Flux Density, diffusive)
- a measure of light intensity in terms of diffusive photons, that are available for photosynthesis
- i.e. the number of diffusive photons falling on a 1 meter square area per second
- only the photons with a wavelength of 400-700nm (visible light) are available for photosynthesis
- unit [?mol/(m?s)]
PPFD(total) = PPFDdif + PPFDdir


ground truth

y -> x

title: Operational Causalities
text:
The data sets discussed here draw their ground truth conclusions from a variety of operational causality definitions. Many of these are not formally defined. This list covers the operation causality definitions we have encountered in the data series, along with a brief description.

“Physics”  — This is a hand-waving, kicking-the-can-down-the-road definition of causality that can be summed up as “someone I trust from a field of science different from mine has said this is true”. This definition does not imply the ground truth is suspect, although it may be. It just means the data set author is using appeal to authority for their ground truth. (The phrase “physics” is used generally here; the actual fields referenced by authors can be anything from medicine to meteorology. It’s all “physics” to us.)
“I don’t know.”  — Your guess is as good as mine. Some of the data sets have ground truths that cannot be referenced, and some of those seem hard to justify. The ground truths are passed along as the original author intended, but the user should be careful when using them.
“Engineered”  — These datasets come from systems built by humans, specifically engineered such that the “detected” cause generates the “effect”. It is different than the “Physics” causality in that the causal mechanism is deliberately engineered.

title: Data Causality Reference Library (dc_reflib)
text:
This Data Causality reference library serves as the high-level documentation for training data sets to use in the computational exploration of causality. The datasets are available at
github: jmmccracken/dc_reflib
The data is available to use however you see fit. Every dataset has an associated “report” in this documentation. They are related by the dataset number. See the examples below.

title: Data Causality Reference Library (dc_reflib)
section: Make a local copy of all the data
text:
Make a local copy of all the data

Clone the above dc_reflib repo
Use your favorite language to read the Parquet. There’s several options, e.g., using Apache Arrow. Let’s use Python for this example.
Read the data:

import pandas as pd
import pyarrow as pa
df = pd.read_parquet('parquet_sets/bivariate/bivariate_0.parquet')

Do something fun with your new “cause-effect” dataframe.

That’s neat, but what’s the point of this documentation? That’s a good question. This example is trivial. You can also download each dataset individually; there’s no need to clone the dc_reflib repo. This documentation is not about reading the data. It is about the data.
The example uses dataset bivariate/bivariate_0.parquet. One series in named “cause” and the other is “effect”. The documentation for this dataset is found at
reports/bivariate/bivariate_0.html
 Every dataset has a corresponding report in this documentation denoted by the dataset filename.






Pop-quiz



Q: I want to run the above example using dataset parquet_sets/bivariate/bivariate_63.parquet. Where is the data report?
A: At reports/bivariate/bivariate_63.html
Q: What about the report for dataset parquet_sets/bivariate/bivariate_33.parquet?
A: At reports/bivariate/bivariate_33.html
You get the point.

title: Other sources of data
text:
The data causality community is active and vibrant. Here are some data sources to help expand your own personal collection of datasets.

Tuebingen Cause-Effect Pairs
A lot of the data in dc_reflib comes from the so-called Tuebingen pairs. It’s a classic database in the data causality field.


Awesome Causality Data
The awesome-causality-data collection focuses on ML/AI training sets. It is part of Awesome Causality which is, in general, pretty awesome. Pro tip: The awesome-causality-algorithms collection links to source code examples of various causality algorithms which often reference articles which often discuss the data they used to train. These little rabbit holes can sometimes lead to awesome datasets that cannot be found anywhere else.


Awesome Causality in CV
This database is awesome, like the last one, but focused specifically on being awesome for computer vision application. Of course, awesome-causality-in-cv data is still awesome even if you’re only interested in non-CV causality.


CMU Benchmark datasets
CMU has a well-earned reputation for excellence in the causality research world. The CMU-Clear benchmark database is a collection of datasets used for benchmarking their software. This is a great resource.


Causality workbench (ML challenge)
The causation and prediction challenge training data was provided as part of the Causality Workbench challenge #1.


Causality workbench (time series challenge)
The cause-effect pairs challenge training data was provided as part of the Causality Workbench challenge #3. If that data link is dead, then you can try the Kaggle data mirror.


Causal (textbook example) data
Several authors have very kindly put up the example data used in their textbooks on causal inference.


Microsoft Benchmark datasets
Microsoft has their own suite of causality tools. They have also provided their benchmark datasets.

title: About Data Causality Reference Library
text:
A collection of data causality tools
The Data Causality Reference Library (dc_reflib) is a collection of data sets for research and algorithm testing. The data is curated specifically for use in testing  data causality (but, of course, it may be useful for other tasks too).


Data causality
The term data causality, also known as exploratory causal analysis or causal discovery, is a subfield of causality studies. It does not need to be considered physics, mathematics, philosophy, computer science, machine learning (and/or AI), computational engineering, statistics, or even just data analysis. It is all of those things. The main thrust of the field is discovering causality, not confirming it.


Ground truths
Suppose I have an algorithm that “discovers” the causal relationships within my data set. How do I know I’m correct? Well, if you are the first to look at that particular data set, then you just move forward with your testing under the assumption that you’re correct. Another option is to apply your algorithm to a data set for which “everyone” already agrees on the causality. We will call this already-agreed-upon causality the ground truth of the data set.


What is “causality”?
Good question. We will not provide an over-arching definition. Rather, each ground truth will provide an operational causality used by whomever formulated the original ground truth. A good example of an operational causality is Granger causality.


Data ownership and copyrights
We are providing the data sets in the same spirit as the original mldata.org and other training/research data repositories. The original data source is provided whenever possible, along with all available license information. Here is mldata’s “disclaimer”. It applies to everything you find on this site too:

“We are acting in good faith to make datasets submitted for the use of the scientific community available to everybody, but if you are a copyright holder and would like us to remove a dataset please inform us and we will do it as soon as possible.”

(OpenML has filled the void left by the untimely demise of mldata.org. It is an excellent source for general ML-focused data sets.)


Do you have any suggested references?
Causality studies are at least as old as formal philosophy and probably as old as human thought. Almost every aspect of the field is fascinating, but I appreciate the overwhelming depth of the literature. Data causality itself is a comparatively young field. Here are some references I find useful (diving into the references of these works will take you down almost all the major rivers of causal studies):

Classic, landmark pillar of the field: Causation, Prediction, and Search
Selfish recommendation: Exploratory Causal Analysis with Time Series Data
For the physicist: Causal Reasoning in Physics
For those who need more options: Which causal inference book you should read
For those who prefer lecture notes with example code: Undergraduate Advanced Data Analysis specifically, Notes Chapter 25
For the ML/AI student who wants to stay up-to-date in the field: Causal Reading Group
For the hip philosopher: Realist Magic: Objects, Ontology, Causality
For the more traditional philosopher: The Oxford Handbook of Causation

title: Note about the dc_reflib images
text:
All of the images presented within dc_reflib that are not obviously data plots or otherwise explicitly sourced are created with permissively licensed generative AI using “causal” prompts.
I probably used Stable Diffusion, but your mileage may vary.
Here’s some fun examples:
